module.title: Self-Discovery Foundations
module.description: Begin your journey by understanding radical honesty, self-enquiry, and the fragmented aspects of yourself

teaching.heading: The Foundation: Inside Reflects Outside
teaching.content:
The inside is the reflection of the outside. That which we carry inside will be reflected outside back at us.

With this statement alone, most of the work can be done, understood, and transcended. Whenever in doubt, in confusion, or in despair, return to this one truth.

You have to be willing to go within. You have to be able to sit with yourself and spend time with yourself in order to unlock all the pieces laying within you.

Without you, there is no one else. Without you, there is nothing else.
keyPoints: Your inner world creates your outer reality
Self-knowledge is the key to knowing the world
Going within is essential for transformation
This journey requires your willingness

practice.title: Grounding & Centering
practice.description: Begin your journey with a grounding practice to anchor yourself in the present moment

journaling.prompt: How far do I want to go in my personal transformation journey? What does my highest self look like?
questions: What brought me to this training?
What am I hoping to heal or transform?
What am I most afraid to discover about myself?

teaching.heading: The Practice of Radical Honesty
teaching.content:
Inside of you there are many aspects. Imagine these as mini copies of you—they have their own thoughts, feelings, and emotions. You as you know yourself are nothing more than the convergence of all these aspects into one.

Radical Honesty means that when you get to meet each part of yourself, you don't look away from what you find. That you don't lie to yourself trying to hide some aspect of you.

In order to see the light, you must shade the darkness. In order to shade the darkness, you must accept it.

These aspects are fragments of you, frozen in time, still reliving the situation that split them from you in the first place. You must hold yourself in all these moments, accepting what is, and who these parts are.
keyPoints: You are made of many aspects or parts
Each part has its own voice and story
Don't look away from uncomfortable truths
Acceptance is the first step to integration

practice.title: Parts Dialogue
practice.description: Begin identifying and communicating with different parts of yourself

journaling.prompt: What part of myself have I been hiding or rejecting? If I could speak to that part, what would I say?
questions: What aspects of myself do I judge most harshly?
What parts of me am I afraid to show others?
Can I offer compassion to the parts I've rejected?

teaching.heading: You Can't Afford Not Knowing
teaching.content:
You can't afford letting one minute more not knowing why you do what you do. You can't afford letting one minute more not knowing what is your intention for everything you do or don't do.

Knowing the reason you do anything and everything will set you free.

Not knowing really is: looking away from oneself, bypassing, not taking responsibility for yourself, lying to oneself, distancing from the truth of who you are.

It is going to take discipline, and you will have to be thorough. The alternative is to remain asleep and allow the natural course of your subconscious and wounded mind to crash against the same shores again and again.
keyPoints: Self-enquiry is a discipline that requires commitment
Knowing your intentions sets you free
Not knowing is a form of self-abandonment
Thoroughness is required for lasting change

practice.title: Inner Inquiry Meditation
practice.description: Practice sitting with yourself and asking 'Why do I do what I do?'

journaling.prompt: Choose one pattern or behavior from today. Why did I do that? What was my true intention? Which part of me was operating?
questions: What patterns do I repeat without understanding why?
What am I avoiding by not investigating my motivations?
Am I ready to take full responsibility for my inner world?

teaching.heading: The Timeline of Your Inner Life
teaching.content:
All is trauma. Everything exists on a spectrum—big trauma and small trauma.

Anytime a trauma was experienced, there was a division within you. Anywhere where there was a split in you, an aspect was created. Anywhere where you didn't understand what was going on and didn't manage to make peace with it, that remained as trauma.

In some space or dimension, that part of you remained intact, frozen, waiting to be figured out. Your story is full of these.

Most of these wounds were created when you were young, very young, and some during teenage years. From there, you mostly increased the severity of the neural pathway that reinforced that pattern.
keyPoints: All unprocessed experiences create fragmentation
Frozen parts remain until they're understood
Most wounds form in childhood
Neural pathways strengthen through repetition

practice.title: Timeline Creation
practice.description: Create a timeline of significant events that shaped your inner self

journaling.prompt: What are the 5-10 most significant events in my life that shaped who I am today? For each one, what emotion did I feel, and what belief did I create about myself?
questions: Which childhood moments still feel 'frozen' in me?
What patterns keep repeating in my life?
Can I identify the original wound behind my recurring struggles?

teaching.heading: Parts Work: Meeting Your Inner Community
teaching.content:
You come to realize you are made of so many selves—so many aspects living together in relative chaos.

You discover the myriad of other constellations that reside within you: the different facets of your personality, the masks you wear, the roles you play in your life. Each aspect has its own story, its own set of experiences and beliefs that shape who you are.

To break free from subconscious programs, you must first become aware of them. This requires deep self-reflection and self-inquiry.

When facing a recurrent issue or challenge in your life, you can start questioning what aspect of you is generating this issue and start getting in touch with those selves residing within you. They will lead you to your core wounds.
keyPoints: Multiple aspects coexist within you
Each part was created for a reason
Parts hold the key to your core wounds
Integration requires awareness first

practice.title: Parts Dialogue Practice
practice.description: Identify a recurring challenge and dialogue with the part creating it

journaling.prompt: What recurring challenge am I facing right now? Which part of me is creating this? If I could speak to that part: When were you created? What are you protecting me from? What do you need?
questions: How many different 'versions' of me can I identify?
Which parts are in conflict with each other?
What would integration of all my parts feel like?

teaching.heading: Understanding What Protects You
teaching.content:
Alcohol, sex, drugs, food, work, studies, charity, TV, sports, shopping, and basically anything that can be turned into an obsession will become a coping mechanism for the emptiness we feel inside.

Anything when in excess can be poison. Anything when in moderation can be medicine.

We're not meant to just stop the 'bad' habits. We're meant to understand why they are there. What are they protecting? What are they a cover for?

These mechanisms helped you survive. They protected you when you had no other tools. Thank them for their service. And now, gently, you can begin to develop new tools, healthier patterns, more conscious ways of being.
keyPoints: Coping mechanisms are protective, not bad
They distance you from uncomfortable truths
Understanding is more important than stopping
Thank them before releasing them

practice.title: Compassion for Your Protectors
practice.description: A guided practice to honor your coping mechanisms before releasing them

journaling.prompt: What do I turn to when I'm overwhelmed? What am I avoiding by engaging in this behavior? What wound or truth lies beneath this coping mechanism?
questions: What are my go-to escapes when life gets hard?
If I couldn't use these coping mechanisms, what would I have to feel?
What healthier alternatives could I develop?

teaching.heading: Choosing Conscious Healing
teaching.content:
There are two ways to heal and grow: The Unconscious Way or The Conscious Way.

You either allow your higher self to guide you towards a situation that will explode in your face for you to learn from it, or you consciously explore your psyche, seeking out all the places that require attention for healing.

You cannot avoid your healing; you can only delay it. Eventually, you will learn the lessons you came here to learn.

The question is: Will you do the minimum to pass the game, or will you give it your best effort since this is your only ride?

The outcome of releasing all the extra weight you've been carrying for decades if not millennia will definitely be felt, and once released, the lightness will carry you effortlessly.
keyPoints: You have a choice: conscious or unconscious healing
Your healing is inevitable
This is your one ride—make it count
The lightness after release is profound

practice.title: Commitment to Your Path
practice.description: A meditation to seal your commitment to conscious healing

journaling.prompt: Am I ready to choose the conscious path? What am I committing to? What do I hope to experience as I continue this journey?
questions: Review the week: What did I discover about myself?
What practices or insights will I carry forward?
What is my intention for Module 2?
